One minute Swift reads to get Swifty-er

Defining Constants and Variables

December 12, 2022

Constants and Variables need to start with the keyword “let” or “var” respectively.

The Swift compiler won’t let you do this 👇
firstName = “Swifty” // ❌

Constants start with the “let” keyword, and can’t be changed after assigned to (they are immutable)
let firstName = “swifty”
firstName = “Notes” // ❌

Variables start with the “var” keyword, and can be changed after assigned to (they are mutable)
var lastName = “notes”

// We can change the variable now
lastName = “Notes”

Defining Constants and Variables

December 12, 2022

Constants and Variables need to start with the keyword “let” or “var” respectively.

The Swift compiler won’t let you do this 👇
firstName = “Swifty” // ❌

Constants start with the “let” keyword, and can’t be changed after assigned to (they are immutable)
let firstName = “swifty”
firstName = “Notes” // ❌

Variables start with the “var” keyword, and can be changed after assigned to (they are mutable)
var lastName = “notes”

// We can change the variable now
lastName = “Notes”
